diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Also known as 'mono', this infection is commonly caused by the Epstein-Barr virus. It can lead to symptoms including fever, fatigue, swollen lymph nodes, and in some cases, a widespread rash.

diagnoses.name: Rubella
diagnoses.description: A viral infection also known as German measles. It typically presents with a rash, fever, and swollen lymph nodes. Thrombocytosis can occasionally occur in these patients.

diagnoses.name: Secondary Syphilis
diagnoses.description: A stage of the bacterial infection caused by Treponema pallidum. It can present with rash, fever, and lymphadenopathy. Thrombocytosis is less common but can occur.

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes inflammation in the walls of some blood vessels in the body. It's more common in children. Symptoms include fever, rash, swelling of the hands and feet, redness in the eyes, and swollen lymph nodes.

diagnoses.name: Rickettsial Diseases
diagnoses.description: Infections caused by Rickettsia bacteria, transmitted by ticks, fleas, and lice. Symptoms often include rash, fever, and swollen lymph nodes. Severe cases can cause thrombocytosis.

diagnoses.name: HIV Acute Infection
diagnoses.description: Early stage of HIV infection can present with fever, rash, and lymphadenopathy. Thrombocytosis can also be observed in some cases.

diagnoses.name: Parvovirus B19 Infection
diagnoses.description: Also known as fifth disease or erythema infectiosum, it can cause a facial rash (slapped cheek), fever, and body rash. It may also lead to thrombocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Toxoplasmosis
diagnoses.description: An infection caused by the parasite Toxoplasma gondii. It can cause flu-like symptoms including lymphadenopathy, rash, and potential thrombocytosis in some individuals.

diagnoses.name: Typhus
diagnoses.description: Caused by Rickettsia prowazekii and transmitted by lice, it can present with fever, rash, and thrombocytosis. Swollen lymph nodes are less commonly reported but can occur.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer of the blood and bone marrow that leads to an abnormal increase in white blood cells. Symptoms can include fever, night sweats, frequent infections, swollen lymph nodes, and a rash. Thrombocytosis is also a feature in certain types of leukemia.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that often presents with symptoms such as dry eyes and mouth, along with possible lymphadenopathy and oral pain.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing inflammation in blood vessels, with symptoms like oral ulcers, genital ulcers (vulvodynia), eye inflammation, and skin rashes.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) compromises the immune system. In advanced stages (AIDS), patients experience lymphadenopathy, oral pain due to ulcers, and various infections.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that begins in lymph nodes causing lymphadenopathy, and it may present with symptoms such as bloating due to spleen enlargement.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs, notably the lungs and lymph glands, causing lymphadenopathy and potential eye symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can cause joint pain, rash, oral ulcers, and lymphadenopathy, among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: Characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain, it can also involve symptoms like difficulty focusing (often termed as 'fibro fog'), and vulvodynia.

diagnoses.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
diagnoses.description: A disorder affecting the large intestine, causing symptoms such as bloating, along with possible associated systemic symptoms such as fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine, causing symptoms like bloating. Other systemic symptoms can include rash and joint pain.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A disease of the central nervous system, leading to demyelination and affecting vision, with possible symptoms including lymphadenopathy due to immune dysregulation.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
reasoning: Increased susceptibility to infection including urinary tract infections, and potential neuropathy leading to hearing loss.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
reasoning: Increased susceptibility to infections, hearing loss due to opportunistic infections, and leukoplakia as an oral manifestation.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
reasoning: Increased susceptibility to infections, hearing loss due to associated anemia or medication, and irritability due to uremia.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Diseases (e.g., Lupus)
reasoning: Increased susceptibility to infections, potential hearing loss, and irritability as symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Malignancies (e.g., Leukemia)
reasoning: Leukoplakia can be associated with malignancy, increased risk of infections due to compromised immunity.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Insipidus
reasoning: Increased susceptibility to UTIs due to frequent urination, and irritability due to electrolyte imbalance.

diagnoses.name: Nutritional Deficiencies (e.g., Vitamin B12 Deficiency)
reasoning: Hearing loss, increased susceptibility to infections, and irritability due to deficiency.

diagnoses.name: Heavy Metal Poisoning (e.g., Lead Poisoning)
reasoning: Increased susceptibility to infections, hearing loss, and irritability as symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Renal Tubular Acidosis
reasoning: Increased risk of urinary tract infections, potential hearing loss due to electrolyte imbalance.

diagnoses.name: Immunodeficiency Disorders (e.g., Common Variable Immunodeficiency)
reasoning: Increased susceptibility to infections as a primary symptom.

diagnoses.name: Allergic reaction
diagnoses.description: An exaggerated response of the immune system to a substance that is ordinarily harmless, which can cause angioedema (swelling), conjunctival injections (red eyes), skin irritation (pruritis), and potentially systemic reactions including vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that can occur rapidly, causing angioedema, pruritis, vomiting, and other systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Contact dermatitis
diagnoses.description: A skin reaction resulting from exposure to allergens or irritants causing pruritis, possibly leading to secondary skin infections that could indirectly affect eye and gastrointestinal health.

diagnoses.name: Atopic dermatitis (Eczema)
diagnoses.description: A condition that makes your skin red and itchy. It's common in children but can occur at any age, leading to pruritis and potentially contributing to secondary infections or systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Food allergy
diagnoses.description: An immune system reaction that occurs soon after eating a certain food, causing symptoms such as pruritis, vomiting, and possibly leading to swelling including angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Drug reaction
diagnoses.description: Adverse effects of medication that can range from mild to severe, including symptoms such as vomiting, pruritis, conjunctival injections, and angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Urticaria
diagnoses.description: A condition where hives and angioedema appear without an apparent trigger, causing severe pruritus and potentially affecting other systems leading to symptoms like vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic condition causing episodes of severe swelling (angioedema) in various parts of the body, including the limbs, face, intestinal tract (leading to vomiting), and airway.

diagnoses.name: Infectious mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Also known as mono, this viral infection can cause fever, sore throat, fatigue, and possibly lead to symptoms like vomiting and skin rash with pruritis.

diagnoses.name: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause widespread inflammation affecting various parts of the body, including skin (pruritis), joints, kidneys, and other organs. Eye symptoms (conjunctival injections) and gastrointestinal symptoms (vomiting) can also occur.

diagnoses.name: Food Allergy
diagnoses.description: An adverse immune response to a food protein. Symptoms can include abdominal cramps, diarrhea, skin rash, and angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that can occur rapidly. Symptoms include angioedema, abdominal pain, difficulty breathing, and diarrhea.

diagnoses.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
diagnoses.description: A common disorder that affects the large intestine, causing cramping, abdominal pain, bloating, gas, diarrhea, and constipation.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD)
diagnoses.description: An umbrella term for chronic inflammation of the digestive tract, primarily including Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. Symptoms often include abdominal pain, severe diarrhea, fatigue, and weight loss.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where the ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine. Symptoms include diarrhea, bloating, and abdominal pain.

diagnoses.name: Eosinophilic Gastroenteritis
diagnoses.description: A rare disease characterized by eosinophilic infiltration of the digestive tract. Symptoms may include diarrhea, abdominal pain, and weight loss.

diagnoses.name: Gastroenteritis
diagnoses.description: An intestinal infection marked by diarrhea, cramps, nausea, vomiting, and fever.

diagnoses.name: Lactose Intolerance
diagnoses.description: Inability to digest lactose, leading to gastrointestinal symptoms such as abdominal pain, diarrhea, and gas after consuming dairy products.

diagnoses.name: Non-Celiac Gluten Sensitivity
diagnoses.description: A condition where individuals experience symptoms similar to those of celiac disease upon consuming gluten but do not test positive for celiac disease.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Idiopathic Urticaria
diagnoses.description: A condition where hives or angioedema appear without a known cause, potentially accompanied by other allergic symptoms like pruritus.

diagnoses: Drug reaction (with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms)
Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response
Foreign body in the respiratory system

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. Symptoms may include headache, difficulty speaking (aphasia), and vision problems such as double vision (diplopia).

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor is a mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain or close to your brain. Depending on the location and size of the tumor, symptoms can include headaches, nausea, and vision problems, and it can affect speech (aphasia).

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: Migraines are a powerful headache that often comes with nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound. Some migraines can be preceded or accompanied by sensory warning signs or symptoms, including vision changes, such as seeing double (diplopia), and difficulty speaking (aphasia).

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including problems with vision (diplopia), speech (aphasia), and severe headaches.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A brain abscess is a collection of pus that develops in response to an infection or trauma. Symptoms often include headache, nausea, seizures, vision problems (diplopia), and in some cases, difficulties with speech (aphasia).

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Meningitis is an inflammation of the fluid and membranes surrounding your brain and spinal cord. Symptoms can include severe headache, nausea, vision problems, and difficulty speaking. It requires immediate medical attention.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often referred to as a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack (TIA) has symptoms very similar to a stroke, like aphasia and double vision, but usually lasts only a few minutes and causes no permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar Circulatory Disorders
diagnoses.description: These disorders affect blood flow to the back of the brain, which controls balance, coordination, and other vital functions. Symptoms can include double vision, dizziness, nausea, and headache.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Encephalitis is inflammation of the brain. Causes can be viral, bacterial, or autoimmune. Symptoms can include headache, fever, confusion, seizures, and sensory changes such as aphasia and double vision.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Guillain-Barré Syndrome is a rare disorder where the body's immune system attacks the nerves. Initial symptoms can include weakness and tingling in the extremities. As it advances, it can lead to symptoms such as difficulty with coordination and balance, vision problems, including double vision, and in severe cases, difficulty with speech.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death, causing symptoms such as weakness, headache, and aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a minibar, a temporary blockage of blood flow to the brain, causing stroke-like symptoms that usually resolve within 24 hours.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain, presenting with symptoms like headache, weakness on one side of the body, and language disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, known for causing headache, fever, and in severe cases, confusion or aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic illness involving the destruction of myelin in the central nervous system, with symptoms including weakness, speech disturbances, and headache.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain, caused by an infection or autoimmune response, leading to symptoms such as headache, aphasia, and altered consciousness.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A collection of pus caused by an infection within the brain tissue, symptoms include headache, neurological deficits, and sometimes language impairments.

diagnoses.name: Hemorrhagic Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when a blood vessel in the brain bursts, leading to intracranial bleeding, and presenting with severe headache, weakness, and difficulties in speaking.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that involves visual disturbances and can include other neurological impairments such as weakness and speech difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance, loss of consciousness, or convulsions, associated with abnormal electrical activity in the brain. Aphasia can occur post-seizure.

diagnoses: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA, formerly Wegener's granulomatosis)
Viral Hemorrhagic Fevers (e.g., Dengue Fever, Ebola)
